Author: BENNETT
Quote: The verbs to go snaky, to go maggoty (cf U.S. maggoty, whimsical) [mean to show anger or annoyance]. Phrases like `mad as a maggot', `mad as a meat-axe' are obviously linked with these expressions (some though not all of which may be heard in Australia; cf. Australian snake-headed, annoyed); whether mad in the sense of angry is a survival of an English provincialism, or has been introduced from America, is not clear.

In smoky little back parlours [in Westport] friendly little groups meet to play `forty-fives' with uproarious oaths and much heavy thumping of the table. For [100] the uninitiated it may be stated that in this game the five-fingers (the five of the trump suit) beats all other cards. The trump suit order is five, jack, ace, king queen - all other suits begin with the king. Non-trump suits win high in red; low in black. Obviously the ace of diamonds is the lowest card in the pack unless diamonds are trumps, in which case it is the fourth best. The word "obviously' in the preceding sentence is a little optimistic - as the ace of hearts (the Maggy) is always the third best trump. It is credibly reported (a) that the game is of Irish origin (b) that there are no written rules (c) that the game can only be learned by playing it, and (d) it is as charactistic of Westport as whitebait or coal.

New Zealand legal words may have a substantial local history. One instance is magistrate. Initially, the term was a synonym for justice of the peace, as it was and largely still is in England.

Generally known simply as magistrates (or SMs) they were legally qualified and exercised increasingly important judicial functions in magistrates courts These had a general jurisdiction - civil, criminal and domestic - that set them apart from English magistrates courts which mainly dealt with petty crime and were presided over by justices of the peace. Magistrates courts were renamed district courts and their presiding judges district court judges in 1981, but the term magistrate in New Zealand denoted stipendiary magistrates rather than justices of the peace, who were and are usually referred to simply as justices or JPs.

In this land two infections assail all comers and vie with one another for first place. These are known as Malaria and Balkan Tap respectively. On the first we need not dwell, but a little information about the latter may be of interest. A similar infection has been met with elsewhere, and in Gyppo Land is known as `magnune', whilst away in our own sunny island I think `dippy' about covered it. Here we have a more or less insidious form of the disease, and no one with six months' residence to his credit may hope to escape. There are two varieties of the disease, malignant and benign. In the latter form the symptoms are easily recognised, and are amenable to treatment; but with the malignant type the victims, quite unconscious of infection, blindly affirm their condition to be normal, This form of the malady has several unfortunate features and is incurable. The percentage in our unit is very high.

Another name given to this useless fish by local fishermen, in Port Chalmers at least, was that of Cadger's-fish.

Author: WILSON
Quote: MEGRIM ... Sometimes called Lantern-fish (because a lantern could be easily shone through it) and known to the Maoris as `mahue' - the fish that is left behind. Known to Christchurch fishermen in early years as the Bludger's Fish. It was the fish they handed out to well-known bludgers who came down to the docks to cadge fish.

Ironically, the most abundant of all New Zealand flounders, the witch or megrim, is useless for eating because of its multitude of long thin hair-like bones and thin watery flesh. The Maori name for this fish - mahue - says it all. It translates as `to be left behind'.

Author: AYLING

Author: HAWES
Quote: As you worked at the pillar - picking, shotfiring, shovelling an' that - it got thinner an' thinner until in the end it looked like a big black tornado, or a tree holding up the sky. That's why the last strand of the pillar is called a 'mahuta'. Things got very tricky at this stage, because the coal in the mahuta was amazingly easy to win; just one gentle prod with yer pick and the coal just blew out... It was tempting to have one last go at the easy stuff in the mahuta, but get it wrong and you brought the roof down on yer head.

Ferns such as the common maidenhair (Adiantum cunninghamii) and the velvet fern (Lastreopsis velutina) occur only in lowland or coastal forest, whereas Microsorum novae-zelandiae and the mountain tree fern (Cyathea colensoi) are confined to montane forest.
Young foliage on many ferns, such as the rosy maidenhair, Adiantum hispidulum, has a decidedly reddish tinge, and in a few species the tips of unfurling fronds are blue.

Propagation of maidenhair ferns from spores is an easy and reliable method.

Author: POLACK
Quote: Round the top a head-board (maihi) was affixed, on which a number of obscene figures were carved. Ibid. 1/206 Over the door-ways and window-sills, handsomely carved boards are fixed, painted in flaming red, these are placed horizontally or in a gable form called maihi, surmounted by a wooden image termed the taupare [a2-acute] warre [e-acute]; some of these figures are exceedingly droll. ... [Caption] The Maihi, a carved board for the front of a house, surmounted by the Toupare [e-acute], or figure-head.

The ridge-boards are carved to represent a number of ngarara, or lizards, running along the roof, and the maihi, or gable-boards, have carvings of the mythological animal known as the manaia - probably a kind of taniwha.

Author: TREGEAR

The carvings (all but the maihi) were finished by the Rotorua school some months ago ...
Notes: Ngata; 1933 June 11 in 1988 Na To Hoa Aroha (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) 3/88

Quote: Maihi, facing-boards joining a gable of Maori house, ornamented with incised carving, deeply incised at lower ends, even perforated: the koruru covers the join at gable, a grotesque figure surmounting the koruru: the upright supports at lower ends are amo.

Author: MONEY
Quote: ... at the junction of the Huranui [Canterbury] with the waters of the lake, we found a diminutive wharry or grass hut, just big enough for four persons to crawl into and pack close; near this was a `mi-mi', or shelter of a different description, to be used as a safe repository for flour and other necessaries, besides paper or any articles that might attract rats.

[?Aust ref.] [Alexander McNab: had Australian experience] This `big house' [built of slabs in 1860] ... was very draughty and McNab at a time when he was suffering from a bronchial ailment, was heard to remark ..., `I tell you what, Johnson, these big houses are a curse. I wish I were back in the maimai with a plate of bark and a run of the dover'.
The ivy on the mimi there is curtained to a screen.
When I'm sitting in my mi-mi / Where the log-fire brightly burns.

Author: WRIGHT
Quote: MAIMAI. - Possibly the name for an old sheep station, although I have not been able to trace one with that name. `Maimai' is, however, the name for an out of way hut; there was one on the Dunstan Range many years ago and another is on Benmore Station.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote: Their mother used to relate how when the Crawfords came they found only one habitation on the run and it was a decidedly primitive one, being built on the principle of an Australian aboriginal maimai.

Author: WILSON

Author: GUNBY

Author: BUTLER
Quote: The few Maories that inhabit this settlement travel to the west coast by way of this river. They always go on foot, and we saw several traces of their encampments - little mimis, as they are called - a few light sticks thrown together, and covered with grass, affording a sort of half-and-half shelter for a single individual.

Author: WRIGHT
Quote: They were big rough sheep on the Maimai, fit to make a shearer's heart / Settle down about his boot-tops on the morning of the start. Ibid. 37 But he wouldn't shear at Maimai.

The weather was appalling and every time we lifted our heads above the brush parapet of the maimai we were met with blasting sleet and salt water which stung the eyes and numbed cheeks and any other exposed extremities.

Author: WILSON

It's all in aid of celebrating our pioneer roots, and a lot easier than going bush with a couple of dogs and a knife or sitting in a freezing maimai hoping for unwitting feathered shot-gun fodder.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote: Another term brought over from Australia [from the 1860's on] was "maimai' for a rough shelter from the weather. Author: BEATTIE
Quote: In 1851 a number of Australian `squatters' came over and took up runholding in Canterbury, but, generally speaking, their advent was some years later in Otago. ... They brought over a number of Australian aborigine words that were new to this side, and which were used a certain amount, usually in a joking manner as far as I know. I have heard some of them fairly frequently used by the `old hands,' sometimes oracularly and sometimes as a semi-humorous quotation. When I was a boy I heard sheep called `jumbucks,' an Australian aborigine term for them, but with the decease of ex-Australian stockmen the word has gone out of use now. Another term brought over from Australia was `maimai,' for a rough shelter from the weather. It was said to be a name for a blackfellow's camp, which I have always seen spelt `miamia,' and which is called `gunyah' or `wurley,' etc., by some tribes. We now apply the name to shooting shelters.

All are commonly called `Maire' alike by settlers and Natives. Black maire usually attains the largest dimensions, and is sometimes 40 feet high or more. Santalum is the least of the group, but even stems of this ... make durable fencing rails. ... All the kinds are confined to the North Island ...

Author: KIRK
Quote: MAIRE.- (Olea cunninghamii and O. lanceolata.) ... BLACK MAIRE.- (Olea apetala.) ... MAIRE.- (Santalum cunninghamii.) These afford fine-grained timber of great density ... All are commonly called `Maire' alike by settlers and Natives. Black maire usually attains the largest dimensions, and is sometimes 40 feet high or more. Santalum is the least of the group, but even stems of this ... make durable fencing rails. ... All the kinds are confined to the North Island ...

Another source of perplexity has arisen from the application of the native name `maire' to all the species alike, as well as to the sandalwood (Santalum cunninghamii), some forms of which closely resemble Olea lanceolata and O. montana in foliage and general appearance ...
maire, a tree (Olea cunninghamii).

Má.i-re (ma.́.e.-r&amacr.; colloq. m&imacr.́.r&emacr.), n. [Maori.] (Bot.) Any one of several New Zealand trees : - (a) Olea lanceolata, of the order Jasmineae; -called white maire by Auckland bushmen. (b) Fusanus Cunninghamii, of the order Santalaceae; called also New Zealand sandalwood. (c) Olea Cunninghamii, of the order Jasmineae; - often called black maire by bushmen. (d) Olea apetala, of the order Jasmineae; - called also broad-leaved maire. (e) Olea montana, of the order Jasmineae; - called also narrow-leaved maire. (f) Eugenia maire, of the order LMyrtaceae; - called by the Maoris maire-tawhaka.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Maire, n. A Maori name applied to three kinds of trees; viz. (I) Santalum cunninghamii, Hook., a sandal-wood; (2) Olea of various species (formerly Fusanus); (3) Eugenia maire, A. Cunn., Native box-wood, but now usually confined to N.O. Santalaceae.

Author: LAING & BLACKWELL
Quote: Olea Cunninghamii (The Black Maire*)[(The Maire*)]. A large tree, with whitish branches. ... The wood is dark brown or black, and is hard, heavy, and durable. ... [fn *] This name is also applied to Mida [salicifolia], ... , and to Eugenia, ...

Author: WILLIAMS
Quote: Maire (ii) 1. n. Olea cunninghamii and other species of Olea

maire n -s [Maori] : any of several New Zealand trees with dense heavy wood: as a : a New Zealand tree of the genus Olea - usu. used with a descriptive qualifier; compare BLACK MAIRE, WHITE MAIRE b : a small light-barked tree (Eugenia maire) with white flowers followed by red berries c : a small and often shrubby tree (Mida myrtifolia) that is related to the Asiatic sandalwood and has glossy glabrous usu. alternate leaves and small brownish green flowers in axillary clusters followed by small red drupes

Mairoa 'dopiness' or sheep sickness: ...
Excellent results have been obtained in the control of 'bush sickness' at Waimiha and 'Mairoa dopiness' at Ngapaenga from the use of cobaltised superphosphate.
Later, New Zealand investigations showed that similar-appearing diseases in this country (bush sickness, Mairoa dopiness and Morton Mains disease) could also be cured and prevented by cobalt.

Author: MONRO
Quote: Behind Toutuki, [the prospective Otago settler] may explore the mountain dreaded by the natives, on account of its being the favourite residence of the mairoero. This is a wild man of the woods, strong, cunning, and mischievous, and addicted to running off with young people and damsels. His body is covered with coarse and long hair, which also flows down from the back of his head nearly to his heels. To com-[263]pensate for this excessive quantity behind, his forehead is said to be bald. He was vividly described to us by a Maori who had seen one long ago, when he was a little boy, and was of opinion that `there is not a more fearful wild-fowl that your mairoero living.'
Notes: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 262-263

Quote: 58. SEA MULLET. ... The Makawhiti or Aua of the Maoris (Agonostoma Forsteri) ... is a common fish ... It is commonly called Herring, from its general resemblance in size and form to that fish, but is easily recognisable from the true Herring by having two fins on the back, ... The Picton Herring, a dried fish commonly known throughout the colony, is the Aua preserved by smoking.
[Maori or Settlers' Name] Herrings, Makawhiti .. [Scientific Name] Agonostoma forsteri

Author: SHERRIN
Quote: MAKAWHITI (Agonostoma Forsteri). ... Called the sea-mullet in other places, but the makawhiti or aua by the Maoris. It is a common fish, Dr. Hector says, obtained at all seasons of the year by fishing from the wharves in the harbours. In Dunedin it is known as the mullet. ... The Picton herring, a dried fish, commonly known throughout the colony, is the aua, preserved by smoking.

Author: H/3/53
Quote: The quartz ... changes in character from crystalline and brown ferruginous in the higher to dense and bluish-grey in the lower parts of the workings - in fact the latter quality represents a so-called `new' or `second make'.
Though a rich patch of black-sand often makes in a single tide it is evident that the first working of the beaches makes a noticeable inroad on the store of gold available.
On the sea-beaches the `black-sanders' often have to wait many weeks or months before a payable patch of black-sand makes.

Author: McGILL
Quote: make a box of make a mess of; eg `He was going well in his first woodchop, until he got distracted by sweat in one eye, missed his groove and made a box of it.' NZA.
The only thing I learned was how to knock the palings off - from the back, with venomous gusto and a hammer - if you make a pig's breakfast of it.
Let's take a walk down to the shed / And list to what they say; / There's So and So, he's on again, / He'll make a quid to-day.
`Get this,' he insists. `To make a quid I've got to swim my cattle out ....'

If he made "a rise" by the sale of gold before the days of Gabriel Reed he must either have had a very confidential buyer, or have been a better "sheperd" of his claim than most men would have been when the temptation was to tell the story of his discovery.
It was Halliday who first conceived the robbery as a "rise" for Christmas.

Source: Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ
Author: HARPER

Author: BELL

Author: PFAFF
Quote: I bought and sold flour ..., got a 3-1/2 oz. nugget from the bottom of a hole that had been left, made a rise of [pounds]300 out of a pocket of gold like horse beans.

Author: VEITCH
Quote: By mid-June [1864] disappointed miners were returning from Picton to try once again to `make a rise' from the banks of the Clutha where it was possible to realise at least a couple of pennyweights a day using only the humble cradle.

Author: PARTRIDGE
Quote: Make a sale . To vomit: New Zealand low: C. 20. B., 1941.

Author: BAKER
Quote: Underworld slang ... t o make a sale , to vomit

Arriving at last at the lake, we made a smoke as a signal for a canoe, and shortly afterwards had the satisfaction of seeing one approaching from Hiruharama; the Poihipi's pa, situated on the opposite side of the lake, which is here about five miles broad.
But the placing of the straw trusses to make a smoke so that the pilot could see how the wind blew had to be very hasty, because the pilot was a little out in his estimate of time.
Even the Australian aborigines can "make a smoke" eloquent.

Each scientist, he advises, should take with him some matches in a well corked glass bottle, as if he strayed from his party and lost his way he could make a smoke by setting fire to the tussock grass.

Source: Crusts: a settler's fare due south

Make.-(1) (Of sheep) to travel; making up, making back, etc.; (2) (of men) arrive at, get to; e.g., m. the station.

Source: Deer Hunter: The Experiences of a NZ Stalker
Author: THOMSON
Quote: We had only found and skinned twelve before we reckoned it was time to make homewards if we wanted to reach camp before dark.
I have always made on every horse I have sold in N.Z. yet.

Author: NEWTON
Quote: ... but it was this dog's `kindness' that so impressed me. The sheep were big, strong, touchy Merino wethers, easily upset, and when Boy finally walked them into the ring they were like three pets. ... When those sheep entered the ring they were really `made', and Bill could have done anything with them.

Castle Hill was the best country I've been on to `make' a dog and it was while there that I at last met with some success on the trial ground. I'd picked up a young heading dog ... which ... was the greatest dog I've ever seen at getting on good terms with - or `making' - sheep. Sheep just never seemed to give any trouble with him.
There were, of course, some high class runs, but the sheep were difficult to "make."

Author: NEWTON
Quote: I'd picked up a young heading dog called Smoke .. was the greatest dog I've seen at getting on good terms with - or 'making' sheep.

Author: LOUGHNAN
Quote: make: when a sheep travels of its own accord it makes up the spur or face. Or it makes back to its favourite basin.

Author: TINSLEY
Quote: The 'make' that had matured for thirteen days was taken off the shelves and loaded on to a trolley.
`A widow's an easy make,' He [sic OEDS] said, `You pedal and let her steer.'

Author: BAXTER
Quote: NORAH ... You thought I'd be an easy make. A Maori bag. Hot Stuff.

If the miners got the land free they would not be able to make salt to their kail on it.
Those doing well do not wish it to be made known, and those making wages say that they are "making tucker."
The miners' gettings were were expressed in such terms as "making tucker," "eeking out an existence," or by some other equally expressive phrase.
He was living in poor circumstances, and started work, he says, in the old diggings in the hope of making tucker.

Author: LUSH

Meanwhile, Lisa Taouma's video installation at the Adam, Measima Samoa, provides a rare revelation of the function and beauty of the Samoan female tattoo on the upper legs, the malu.

"We are all aware as Samoans that if a malu or tatau is tattooed without the agreement of the family its results are fatal," Stanley told the Samoa Observer newspaper. Editor of the paper, Mataafa Keni Lesa, said according to superstition if a male is tattooed with a malu it can cause both the wearer and the tattooist to die.

The most common species are the poka (Dicksonia squarrosa) and the katote (Hemitelia smithii); the stem and fronds of the latter are sometimes used as food for cows. The mamaku (Cyathea medullaris) is local, and has not been observed south of Halfmoon Bay.

Salt attributes our "man drought" to the fact that young single males are more likely to stay away permanently or come back with an overseas born partner. .. Richard Bedford says the man drought is real but not nearly as bad as Salt says - and OE isn't causing it. .. Man Drought is due, suggests Bedford, to the compounding and cumulative effects of four factors: more young men than women dying in accidents and from suicide; higher net migration loss among men; more women than men coming to New Zealand from some countries and a tendency for males to be under-counted at censuses.

Ibid. 18 [inherent in land] `Kia mau te mana o te whenua' is another expression now in frequent use, i.e., `hold fast the mana of the land'. ... This is altogether a new application of the term; perhaps it has ben adopted in consequence of the Queen's Sovereignty over the Island having been translated as the Queen's mana. Quote: So ... the scouts left their secret bed among the ferns and the mangemange[es-acute] and crept cautiously out to the Waimarino track.

Author: BOSWELL
Quote: Our mattresses were of mange-mange, a bush creeper of dense tangled growth, sufficiently springy if not very soft when green, ....

Quote: A climbing fern often forming an almost impenetrable tangle in the forest of the far north is that known as [117] the MANGE-MANGE (Lygodium) ...

Author: KEENE
Quote: mangemange: a climbing fern.

Author: MOORE & IRWIN
Quote: LYGODIUM ARTICULATUM (Schizaeceae). The strangest thins about mangemange is that the true stem is very short but the leaf goes on growing at its tip and may be many metres long. In kauri forest these tough wiry leaves wind round trees and shrubs in an impenetrable network. Such a tangle makes thin strong vines suitable for securing thatch on a whare, as wire might be used today.

Author: RICHARDS

One of the greatest ornaments there was the mangemange, or Lygodium articulatum, displaying as it twined around the branches its varied form of foliage.

New Zealand's extraordinary climbing fern, the Maori's mange-mange.. belongs to a family which has changed very slightly, if at all, since Triassic days.

Grown in the same way as Mangere pole, but in the warmer areas here, they [sc. yard long beans] can be very vigorous and highly productive annual climbers.

Author: HAY
Quote: In the bays and tidal rivers are the mango or sharks - the most highly-prized food-fish - the tamure or schnapper, the whapuka or rock-cod, the kahawai or mackerel, the porahi or herring, the kanae or mullet, the patiki or sole, and many others. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. In the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga).

Author: SHERRIN
Quote: TIGER SHARK (Lamna glauca). ... In New South Wales it is called the blue pointer, and, as Mr. Hill tells us, is `not only a very powerful, but perhaps the most bold of any of the large sharks visiting our shores. ... [118] Although there is some doubt on the subject, Lamna glauca is considered to be the mako of the Maoris, which is mainly found in the neighbourhood of Mayor Island. ... Mango, it should be remembered, seems [119] almost a generic name for shark in the North, as there is the mango-taniwha, a large variety; the mango-pare, the hammerheaded shark; the mango-reremai, the common dog-fish; the mango-pekepeke, and the mango-aruroa.

Author: BEATTIE
Quote: When in a hurry, or feeling orthographically tired, he [the southerner] calls the big manuka `kaikatoa.' A southern Maori once said to me:- `We did not pronounce the word manuka like some northerners who throw the accent forward and say `man-u-ka,' nor like the bushmen, who say `m'nooka,' but about halfway between these two pronouncing each part clearly as mah-nook-a.' Unless my hearing deceives me this throws the emphasis on the central syllable while leaving the first syllable clearly pronounced. It is a remarkable fact that while the manuka is so common its name is so seldom used in the composition of place-names.

ma[a]nuka, a shrub (Leptospermum scoparium), commonly called tea-tree, because Cook's people used the fresh young leaves infused for tea; but very often mis-spelt ti-tree - ti being something totally different, the cabbage tree (Cordyline). The tree-manuka is kanuka, with smaller leaves and smaller flowers than the scrub-manuka, and it is the kanuka that is usually sold for firewood. I spoke to a dealer about it, and he said they dodged the confusion by selling it as T.T. There is a crimson-flowering variety of manuka known in England as a rarity, but by means of slips (not seed) it has become not uncommon. The starry-flowered manuka would have been adopted as the national flower but for the fact that it is too prolific, and apt to become a nuisance. It has a second name, kahika[a]toa but that is discouraged on account of its spelling being so nearly the same as kahikatea, the white pine, though in sound they are quite different, the macron in hahika[a]toa causing an apparent accent which, when observed, clearly differentiates the two words: it is not an accent, however, but a lengthening of the vowel.

MANUKA BLIGHT [heading] Since first noted in the Canterbury district in 1937, the scale insect Eriococcus scoparium, has ... become widely established.

The manuka blight was first introduced into the [Hawkes Bay] region in 1945 ... [fn] The blight is caused by the action of a small sucking insect which feeds on the sap of the manuka and which secretes large quantities of a clear sticky substance known as `honey-dew'. A black sooty mould forms on this secretion. A combination of sap loss and mould slowly kills the plant.

Ibid. 42 Sandstone Gravels - These consist of yellowish known sandstones gravels, well rounded, and fairy uniform in size, the material seldom exceeds 6 in. in diameter, and is generally much decomposed. The gravels form the well-known `Maori bottom' of the Maniototo and Manuherikia basins.
The brownish quartz-sandstone gravels, locally [at Naseby] known as Maori Bottom, are seldom payably auriferous.

There are no less than some five of six of these bottoms.. the intervening layers between each bottom being composed of white quartz and conglomerate boulders, intermixed with "Maoris," black sand, and school its detritus.

There are very few cockroaches, the ones met with in habitations being exotic ones; the best known native species is the unpleasant stink-roach, often incorrectly called the `black beetle', and too frequently referred to as the `Maori bug' - a term that should be avoided because it is a name just as objectionable to the Maori as the insect's odour is to the Europeans who coined the name; however, it has been said that the term is a corruption of the original and inoffensive European name of `kauri bug'.
A child hears phrases like ... `Black as a nigger', or hears ... a certain kind of beetle called a `Maori bug'....

We admire native bush, pasture, or game; but M. hens (woodhens), M. cabbage [the European cabbage run wild--A.W.], and M. onion (Chrysobactron bookeri) are caricatures of their English namesakes. Author: BEATTIE
Quote: Pora is an introduced vegetable run wild. The word `pora' means a ship. The plant flourished up the rivers, and the first settlers called it `Maori cabbage'. The lists also call it Pora-kawa-kawa, but this is amalgamating two names, for the kawakawa is another vegetable run wild.

Author: HEBERLEY
Quote: The Natives took a cask of lime, and thought it was cask of flour, they went to work and made dumplings of it and naked them in what is termed a Maori Copper.

We roasted half a sheep in a Maori copper, that is first dig a hole in the ground in proportion to the thing you want to cook. Line the bottom and sides with stones as big as a breakfast cup then light a fire over them till they are quite red hot throwing in more loose stones to put on the top. Then take out all the ashes, wrap your meat in green grass put it in the pit, throw the loose stones on top and cover the whole with sods of grass, clay or anything that will keep the steam in, three or four hours will cook your meat to perfection.

A special report on the subject which the medical statistics branch of the Health Department has issued makes this point [of the prevalence of ear, nose, and throat disease among Maoris]. For more than half a century the `Maori ear' had been regarded in medical practice as a most unrewarding condition to treat in more ways than one and by both parties concerned, the report said. If future generations of Maori children retained their greater susceptibility to ear disease, every year would add to the size of the problem till it might become too big ever to be solved.

Author: LAWLOR
Quote: [Dick Harris in Introduction] The reader should be warned that the apparently phonetic spelling of English as it is commonly supposed to be spoken by Hori is not to be accepted as authentic `Maori English'.

It is sometimes stated that a Maori child's spoken vocabulary often lacks idiom. It is true that he has limited access to the wide range of expressions that enrich the English language, but `Maori English' is perhaps excessively idiomatic in its use of colloquial phrases, slang, and short, pithy expressions that convey more meaning than is in bare words. The range is not wide , however, and the expressions are used repetively, often to reinforce a meaning rather than add to it.

`Restricted Codes and Maori English' [title] A recent (1971) N.Z. Department of Education publication, Maori Children and the Teacher (henceforth MCT), discusses at some length the question of `Maori English' and the language of Maori children. [Ibid 68] I hope to have shown, in this review, that we should not accept uncritically the assumption that Maori English constitutes a restricted code or that Maori children are cognitively deficient. We know that Maori English is different from Standard English and we are aware of some of the factors that make it so. ... evidence and ...

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Maori, n. (pronounced so as to rhyme with Dowry). (I) The name used to designate themselves by the Polynesian race occupying New Zealand when it was discovered by the white man, and which still survives. They are not aboriginal as is commonly supposed, but migrated into New Zealand about 500 years ago from Hawaii, the tradition still surviving of the two great canoes Arawa and Tainui in which the pioneers arrived. They are commonly spoken of as the Natives of New Zealand. -->(2) The language of the Maori race. -->(3) Applied to anything pertaining to the Maoris or their language. See Pakeha. -->There is a discussion on the word in the `Journal of Polynesian Society,' vol. i. no. 3, vol. ii. no. I, and vol. iii. no. I. Bishop Williams (4th ed.) says that the word means, `of the normal or usual kind.' The Pakehas were not men to whom the natives were accustomed. So Maori was used as opposed to the Europeans, the white-skins. Kuri Maori was a name used for a dog after the arrival of other quadrupeds called also kuri. Wai maoriwas fresh-water, ordinary as opposed to sea-water. Another explanation is that the word meant `indigenous,' and that there are kindred words with that meaning in other Polynesian languages. First, `indigenous,' or "of the native race,' and then with a secondary meaning, `ours.' (See `Tregear's Maori Comparative Dictionary,' s.v.) The form of the plural varies, The form Maoris is considered the more correct, but the form Maories is frequently used by good writers.
(Settler's letter) The mauris (dark men) .... parkias (white men) ...

Bishop Williams (4th ed.) says that the word means, `of the normal or usual kind.' The Pakehas were not men to whom the natives were accustomed. So Maori was used as opposed to the Europeans, the white-skins. Kuri Maori was a name used for a dog after the arrival of other quadrupeds called also kuri. Wai maori was fresh-water, oridinary as opposed to sea-water. Another explanation is that the word meant `indigenous,' and that there are kindred words with that meaning in other Polynesian languages. A `Maori' gate is always a weird contraption made of bits of wire, string, parts of an old iron bedstead - something so complicated that it defies the ingenuity of the non-expert either to open or close. Author: BUCK
Quote: The smallest sociological unit is the biological family, which the Maoris termed whanau, derived from whanau, to give birth . ... The term hapu (pregnancy) was used to denote this expanded family group for it expressed the idea of birth from common ancestors ... The term iwi (bone) was brought into current use to include all the hapu descended from common ancestors and thus related to each other by a blood tie. To denote the groupings in English, the iwi has been termed tribe and the hapu a sub-tribe.

This essay is a report on the ... distribution of the Maori [fn 1] in northern New Zealand - ... [fn 1] A distinction may be made between `Maori' and Maoris' as plural forms. The former refers to the Maori people as a whole and as an ethnic and cultural entity; the latter designates individuals of this people (cf The Coming of the Maori and Some Modern Maoris.

Author: DUFF
Quote: This raises the question of what we mean by the term Maori. Why should Kupe be termed a Maori, if (according to Maori tradition) he was a Society Islands voyager of some 1,000 years ago who touched at New Zealand in the course of exploring voyages and returned to his homeland? By what greater right can we apply the term to Toi who arrived from the same part of the Pacific 200 years later to settle in New Zealand, or to the numerous voyagers subsequent to Toi and culminating in the Hawaiki Fleet of 1350? Every immigrant from tropical Polynesia did not become a Maori the moment he stepped ashore in New Zealand. The culture which we have come to know as Maori was undoubtedly the end product of a long period of local development, probably not reaching its final perfection of form until after the visit of Tasman. The use of the term Maori (lit. normal, ordinary or proper) to distinguish the Polynesian inhabitants of New Zealand from the intrusive European is even more clearly a late development and certainly post-European.* [fn] Williams (1921) notes no literary use before 1850 of the Maori in its present sense. Scholefield (1945) puts its use back to 1840, in the translation of the Treaty of Waitangi. McNab, quoted by Shrimpton and Mulgan, without the reference being cited, states that its earliest use was in 1818.

(Profesor Joan Metge) Recent letters opposing the use of the word `Pakeha' claim that it means `foreigner' or `stranger'. ... Whatever the word meant when it was first bestowed, it has taken on a new and special meaning. Maoris today use it to identify non-Maori New Zealanders of European and especially of British stock, people whom they recognise as having a history of residence and commitment to this country. Maoris use it not only to distinguish Pakehas from themselves but to couple them with themselves. The word has meaning only within the New Zealand context, in relation to and partnership with `Maori', the shared reference point being the land of Aotearoa/New Zealand.

Maori land and the terms relating to it are of course unique to New Zealand. DNZE defines it (in part) as land for which Maori customary or legal title is recognised as valid. This has a circular air and the contrast of customary and legal tile is confusing, since customary title is itself a title recognised by the law. At law, Maori land is land owned by Maori under customary or Maori freehold title.

I have speculated that perhaps this similarity provides some support for the notion that lines of the maori potato came to Aotearoa direct from South America and not via Europe.

The Maori Potato The ancient potato cultivars commonly referred to as Maori potatoes may be descended from tubers given to the Maori by early explorers, or they may have come direct from South America with the early colonisation of the Pacific. Doug Yen ... now at the Bishop Museum appears to have been the first to collect and study these early potatoes (The Potato Journal summer 1961/61: 2-5) and he refers to the introductions by de Surville in 1769 and 1772 and by Cook in 1773. Yen also refers to the possible introduction direct from South America, since Callao in Peru and Acapulco in Mexico were provisioning ports for whaling vessels. This year I grew `Urenaka' (Yen refers to `Urenika') ... and I understand this cultivar came from the East Coast. It is certainly an unusual potato with purplish stems and tubers. ... Yen ... notes that they resemble the storied (Iodine) potato of Ireland, used as a talisman against illness. ... Audrey [Eagle] said that when she gave some [similar] tubers to a Maori lady she exclaimed `ah, rokekuri'.

Undoubtedly there was good blood among these horses, though the great majority would come into the somewhat elastic classification of `Maori weed.' In actual fact, there was no reproach in the term, Born and reared on the inhospitable plains, a horse developed a stamina that no finely-bred animal possessed. Well broken in and handled properly, a `weed' would get through more hard toiling in a day than the average equine would put behind him in a week. Author: CAMERON
Quote: To a certain extent, in fact, Maoritanga is not a matter of inheritance; it is a matter of he manawa, of `how one feels.' Ibid. 75 But when Sir James Carroll and other leaders of the Young Maori Party wanted a term to denote the way of life of their people, they took the completely-assimilated modern meaning of the word `Maori' - which, thanks to the pakeha, transcended tribal boundaries - and coined a new meaning for `Maoritanga.' The meaning of the term is debated and discussed, analyzed and defined, used and abused with great frequency in the present upsurge of interest in Maori culture and traditional ways of thinking, feeling, and acting. A second Maori renaissance seems to be under way, aided by this all-embracing term and strengthened by the success of the first one in the early decades of this century.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Mapau, n. a Maori name for several New Zealand trees; called also Mapou, and frequently corrupted by settlers into Maple, by the law of Hobson-Jobson. The name is applied to the following. The Mapau - Myrsine urvillei, De C., N.O. Myrsineaem; sometimes called Red Mapau. Black M. - Pittosporum tenuifolium, Banks and Sol., N.O. Pittosporeae; Maori name Tawhiri. White M. - Carpodetus serratus, Forst., N.O. Saxifrageae; Pittosporum eugenoides, A. Cunn.; Maori name, Tarata (q.v.); called also the Hedge-laurel (q.v.), Lemon-wood, and New Zealand Oak. See Oak. The first of these (Myrsine urvillei) is, according to Colenso, the only tree to which the Maoris themselves give the name Mapau. The others are only so called by the settlers.

Based around the Ruapehu area and stretching as far as the Whanganui River area, the Maramatanga is a unique series of beliefs. Although the majority of its practitioners belong to the Roman Cathlic branch of Christianity, the teaching of Rikiriki, who was both a prophet and a healer, are designed to being together the old and the new, rather than the outright rejection of the old ways preferred by most Protestant missionaries.

Maramatanga literally means enlightenment or understanding. The people of the Maramatanga belong to a prophetic and religious movement who by faith, story, waiata and ritual have sustained their identity and autonomy in the face of an overwhelming Pakeha society.

Girls' marching as a sport or competition was started in Auckland by Miss Jean Stevenson, General Secretary of the YWCA in Auckland in the early 1920s. Head Word: Mascot of HMS New Zealand, the
Author: FRASER & McGIBBON
Quote: MASCOT OF H.M.S. NEW ZEALAND, THE: The Maori `Piu-piu,' or cloak of black and white strips of flax and feathers, and the carved greenstone amulet figure, ("Tiki") worn round the neck (similar to the old battle insignia of Maori chiefs) presented to the battleship New Zealand. They were given by an old Maori Chief in 1913, with the injunction that they must always be worn when the ship was in action, the chief prophesying that they would keep the ship from harm. Both "Piu-piu' and `Tiki' were worn at the Battle of Jutland by the Captain - to the great satisfaction of the crew, who, it is told, before the battle began took special measures to find out that the Captain was actually wearing the ship's mascot. On another occasion, when an action seemed imminent, the New Zealand mascot was also worn. On that occasion, word was specially passed round the decks among the men - `It's all right, he's got 'em on!' The New Zealand at Jutland escaped with only one shell hit, and had no casualties. Writing home after Jutland an officer said: "This ship bore a charmed life and suffered to the smallest extent though we were right in it the whole time.'

First, in the great maritime strike of 1890, then the 1913 strike which saw Massey's Cossacks ride into our history and then in the great 1951 lockout, the watersiders were defeated, leaving a bitter legacy that divided the union movement and lingers to this day.

[The fence] was still being put up in 1913 when a general strike broke out, [prompting dozens of volunteers, including farmers on horseback (nicknamed Massey's Cossacks), to stand in front of it to guard the wharves.

Over 1000 police and 'special' mounted constables were enrolled from the farming community by the Massey Government. Nicknamed 'Massey's Cossacks' by the strikers, the local farmers eagerly responded to the call to quell the 'Red Feds'.
The dispute became notorious for the violence against and by the "specials" or Massey's Cossacks" -- temporary police recruited from country areas to control striking workers.

Masting - the synchonised [sic] fluctuation in flowering and seeding among plant populations - is more common in New Zealand than in other countries... A fortnight ago Southern Beeches .. were masting so enthusiastically, the air was filled with vast quantities of pollen.

That the humble beech seed is ultimately responsible for all this carnage and chaos reflects a feature of New Zealand flora called "masting"... These seasons of heavy flowering are commonly known as mast years.

Author: KERR
Quote: In New Zealand, Maori men knew that cracks in the heart-wood of old matai trees often exude a liquid, matai beer, a stimulating drink that weary white bushmen later discovered.

Author: HUTT
Quote: Matai beer was described by a Taihape newspaper in 1912 as tasting "like used machine oil... When a deep swig is absorbed, one has all the sensations of having swallowed a lighted kerosene stove."

... I dimly remember as a youngster in the days when the Forty-Mile Bush was still standing, such a drink as `matai beer' was sometimes spoken of amongst bushmen. Apparently it was made from the sap of the matai tree, extracted by the simple process of boring an auger-hole in the trunk. ... Can any old-timer axeman give any information concerning this liquor.

When I was a boy I lived in Carterton, and that was in the 'sixties, when there was little else than bush there ... I have frequently drunk the matai beer which gushes out of the centre of the tree when the axemen get to the heart. The flavour varies, but always has something of the tang of resin about it, though it is not at all a bad drink. ... I never heard of this matai beer being intoxicating; ...

Author: MACKAY
Quote: In the rip-roaring times of the King Country, Matai beer was a favourite with those who were strong enough and tough enough to drink it. It went out of favour when `cruisers' for the various timber mills complained that much good yellow pine was being ruined through the number of deep axe cuts and even auger holes in the standing trees, made to let the potent juice run into waiting pannikins or buckets. The favourite recipe for this form of wood alcohol represented the addition of three or four cupsful of the sap to each gallon of `ordinary' liquid refreshment. That the resultant mixture had a pretty hefty kick to it may be judged from this description handed in to the Taihape newspaper (1912): `Matai beer is the term used to describe a certain brand or grade of alcoholic brew. It may be identified easily. It smells like an ancient bar room the morning after. It tastes like used machine oil, only a very low grade of machine oil.

Author: OWEN & PERKINS
Quote: But [bushmen] used to make concoctions of their own, and the most popular ... was matai beer. ... When you felled a big matai, a really mature black pine ... you would see the main artery in the heart of the tree gushing out the life liquid. ... It wasn't the sap; this was not related to that. It was a pure clear liquid, and it gushed out like the main artery gushing blood. But that used to be prized, and it would be caught in a billy. That was really something. It was beautiful and cool and sweet to drink as it was, but some of the blokes used to bung in maybe a handful of raisins and sugar and cork her up and let her ferment, and whether that fluid had any other properties in it or not I don't know, but you could get quite a potent drink from it.

Author: FULLER
Quote: MATAI BEER [title] I have been told by old bushmen and Maoris about making beer from the sap of the matai tree ... Apparently when the tree was being cut down the watery sap was collected, more water was added and also some ordinary beer, or yeast. It was left to ferment and was reputed to be quite strong though I have not been able to find any written evidence of this.

A mataitai reserve is an identified traditional fishing ground established in fisheries waters for the purpose of customary food gathering.
Proposed mahinga mataitai (sea-food gathering) reserves will be set aside for exclusive use by particular Maori tribes... The mataitai move split the Government and will likely split New Zealanders.
The new rules will allow local Maori groups to set up self-managed fishing reserves (mataitais) around traditional fishing spots or reefs.

The Government says it wants to protect 10 per cent of New Zealand's marine environment by 2010 in a representative network of "marine protected areas"; either in the sanctity of a marine reserve or some form of fisheries management regime such as mataitai or taiapure (fishing reserves).

Last month Parliament declared the coastline from Whirinaki to 28km north a "mataitai" - a reserve that recognises and provides for customary food-gathering by Maori in areas special to tangata whenua. ... The mataitai off Whirinaki is known as "Moremore". ... Mataitai were introduced as part of the Treaty of Waitangi (Fisheries Claims) Settlement Act 1992 to provide a tool for Maori to manage all non-commercial fishing grounds. ... Rock Lobster Council chief Dary Sykes said Moremore was the first mataitai to affect commercial fishing. ... One whakatauki, or proverb, describes this time as Matariki ahunga nui: Matariki, provider of plentiful food... Matariki marked a turning point in the gardening year... The appearance of Matariki is auspicious for predicting the coming year's harvests.
The Maori new year started on June 23, after the first new moon following since the yearly reappearance above the horizon before dawn of the Pleiades star cluster (Maori : Matariki).

My apologies.. if I did not make it sufficiently clear in describing Matariki that the celebration of a New Year marked by the winter solstice is the "tradition" that links it with Hogmanay and the Saturnalia. It did not occur to me that this might be misconstrued as a suggestion that Maori had been celebrating Matariki here for millennia.

Matariki is a time for harvesting and Thornley says it is a good time to gather herbs from the bush... "It's a good time to pick pikopiko. Matariki is a time for putting the past to rest and looking forward to the future."

Winter might not be the easiest time of the year to rise before dawn, but it's the only chance to see Matariki, a cluster of stars that heralds the Maori New Year... Matariki is celebrated differently by each iwi,. but the New Year begins with the first new moon after the appearance of Matariki.
Towards the end of May each year the constellation Matariki, also known as the Pleiades, rises on the north-east horizon around half an hour before dawn.

[Hdg] Matariki celebrations continue at Te Papa... In the last week of May, the star cluster Matariki, or Pleiades, appears in our dawn sky. For most iwi, the Maori New year begins with the first new moon after the appearance of Matariki.

Author: PARK
Quote: At Te Kuiti I never saw the Pleiades because of the hills. Years afterwards, when I lived on the broad plains, I saw that heliacal rising, a handful of sparks on the horizon, until the sun blew them out. Mr Tawhai called them Te Matariki.

But what is Matariki and why has this ancient tradition, which hasn't been much practised by Maori for the past 150 years, suddenly taken off again? Matariki is the Maori name for the beautiful little cluster of stars that is commonly known as the Pleiades or the Seven Sisters, Roughly translated, it means "little-eyes".... At the end of May, Matariki reappears in the morning sky, rising just before dawn... So Matariki is linked to the universal celebration of midwinter. It's the antipodean equivalent of the Scots' hogmanay or the Chinese New Year - in fact it has traditions that go back further than the Roman Saturnalia.

I gave him the information required, and asked him to come and stay with me for the night, which he did. ... He found it there the next day. I came upon him working in the creek, when he sang out: `Hullo, mate! - I have got him.' And so he had. Both of us worked hard for a week or so, and got a few ounces with a tin dish. Author: HENDERSON
Quote: To break the law of tapu was to die of mate Maori, the sickness caused by an uneasy Maori conscience or the influx of demons.

Author: BINNEY et al.
Quote: Inexplicable sickness, mate Maori, is often attributed to evil forces living in the human body; their extraction, possible only by faith in the healer, is a major part of the role of a tohunga.

The youth had been to see a Maori spiritual healer, a tohunga, but his mother said tapu forbids her from discussing his diagnosis.

Author: WILSON
Quote: The fact that large, wet flies tied in a particular way to imitate small fish are known by three different names causes a lot of confusion. As patterns from all three countries are used here, the confusion can be understood. Quote: Mauri - ethos, life-force or principle, life-style, belief. This term applies to both animate an inanimate things. Houses, land, trees, forests, buildings, hills etc. can have a life-force of their own. So can the front (atea) of a marae, a speech, the kumara, or the taniwha of a river. Maoris strongly believe in mauri, and just as a life force may wax or wane depending on a person's health or status, so can his or her `mauri'. Lack of mauri can cause a person to die.

If a Maori is genuinely disturbed, in Maori terms, the answer again is to restore their mauri (life force), as for physical illness. This is particularly true for mate Maori, Maori sickness, which arises from spiritual and social causes, not physical ones (Pakehas would call it psychosomatic).

Supporting the ridge-pole is a centre-post on which are figures of ancestors. The floor is often covered with flax matting, and visitors take off their shoes before entering. New Zealand works with Australia on a joint programme called the Equipment Energy Efficiency (E3) Programme. The E3 programme develops energy efficiency measures for a range of residential, commercial, and industrial products which economic and environmental benefits to consumers and businesses. The E3 allows both countries to honour their commitments under the Trans-Tasman Mutual Recognition Arrangement (TTMRA).
Will I have to replace all my light bulbs once the MEPS come into effect? No. The MEPS is intended to stop the product being sold, but does not affect those already in use.

The New Zealanders are very religious men. Their priests lead them out to a quiet spot where they can pray. The priest spreads out a holy mat with marks on it which means something they have great faith in. He kneels down beside the mat, then a row of worshippers kneel all round him, with another row bending over them, and another row standing behind them. The worshippers throw their offerings on to the holy mat, and the priest places two coins on a short piece of polished wood which he calls a kip, and raising his eyes to the sky, he throws up the coins as an offering to Allah. All the worshippers raise their eyes also to the sky, and then bow solemnly over the mat, and say together, `God Almighty', and the priest answers, `A pair of Micks', which means that the offerings are not accepted, or he may say, `Oh Lord, he has done 'em again', and the joyful cries of some of the worshippers show that Allah is pleased, and so they, too, are glad.

Quote: Caving method: Also known as the `milking cow'; it applied to an area of several acres where the Mine Lake is now. The method started with the collapse of the large arches on the Martha reef about No. 1 shaft, and was later systematically developed by a series of sub-levels on Nos 7, 8 and 9 levels which were used to weaken this section of country and cause it to run so that it could be drawn off through chutes. It operated for a quarter-century and is conservatively estimated to have yielded over a million tons of good run-of-mine grade ore. Ibid. 327 Milking Cow or Caving Block: (See also caving method). A block of country between Nos 1 and 6 shafts and Junction Road, where the Mine Lake is now, which originally contained a network of large reefs and which collapsed after the removal of undergound support pillars and arches and became a caving area. It is estimated that over 1,000,000 tons of ore of good grade was obtained on Nos 7 and 8 levels by caving methods during a period of 25 years.

Author: GRAHAM
Quote: MINNOW or WHITEBAIT (INANGA) Austrocobitis attenuatus (Jenyns)... For a long time it has been known to the Maori and to Europeans that our New Zealand Whitebait is the young of a native freshwater fish commonly known as Minnow, or Inanga or Hiwi to the Maori, and erroneously called a Trout. ... The early settlers called it Maori Trout, Native Trout, Rock Trout and Minnow. But it is not a Trout. Nor is it a Minnow, through it resembles the English freshwater Minnow. While the name Trout is not correct, it is and will always be known as such by farmers and naturalists. In the Bay of Plenty, Whitebait is known to the Maori as Porohoe.

Author: DUFF
Quote: THE [AUTHOR'S] USE OF THE TERM MOA-HUNTER [heading] [XII] ... Because this hunting economy and imported artifact styles coincided with the then unknown period of the extermination of the Moa in particular, Skinner, Duff and Buck revived the term Moa-hunter Maori to distinguish the first phase of ecological adaptation from the climax Classic Maori phase of the eighteenth century, with such new elements as agriculture, the fortified village, warfare, and artifact styles evolved within New Zealand. [XII] The term Moa-hunter follows the practice in culture-phase designation of coining a label of contrast. Although Moa-hunter Maoris gathered shell-fish and hunted all available birds, fish, seals and small whales, the cultural and economic phase is conveniently designated from the Moa as the largest and most spectacular game animal available during man's first adaptation to the environment and the one no longer available in the Classic Maori era. The term Moa-hunter is preferred here to the longer `Archaic Phase of New Zealand East Polynesian', too easily corrupted to `Archaic Maori', with `Archaic' meaning only `early'.
moa hunter n. N.Z. an anthropologist's term for an early Maori.

The grazing management system was modified to a considerable extent from that of traditional set stocking to one known as mob stocking or mobbing. In such a method of grazing, paddocks are heavily stocked in turn so that the pasture herbage available is used to the fullest extent in the shortest possible time.

Woolshed terms.-The water pot is a tin of water (usually disinfected) which a shearer has tied by him to wet his shears in. To gap shears is to make (accidentally) a g. in the edge. Sweat rag: kept by the shearer to wipe his brow. To grind (shears) is always used without the noun. A shearer never `grinds his shears.' Moccasins are the sacking slippers which most shearers make to work in. Unless the owner of the station is a careful, observant man, he will hardly recognise his own wool pack tops.

Mock Whitebait. - Raw fish (any kind), 2 tablespoons flour, teaspoon salt, cayenne, egg glazing, breadcrumbs, frying fat, lemon. Free the fish from the bone, and cut into strips about one and a half inches long. Mix flour, salt, and cayenne. Dip the pieces of fish in the flour, then in egg, and coat with crumbs. Fry a golden brown in hot fat. Drain. Serve piles high on a hot dish, garnished with slices of lemon.

The Moeraki boulders are an assemblage of near-perfect spheres that lie like discarded cricket balls on an east Otago beach. The largest of them span more than two metres in diameter and weigh over seven tonnes.[15] Claims have been made that the Moeraki boulders are the only rocks of their kind in the world... The truth is that concretions are common, but are usually only a few centimetres in diameter, irregular in shape and unlikely to impress... To Moeraki's Ngai Tahi residents, the boulders' origin is intertwined with the arrival of kumara from distant Hawaiki. According to Te Rungana o Moeraki, the great waka Arai-Te-Uru was wrecked during a fierce storm at Matakaea (Shag Point), just south of Moeraki. The boulders are food baskets that washed ashore after being thrown overboard to lighten the load. The Katiki concretions are said to be kumara tubers and seeds from the same wreck.
Along the way she [sc. Shona McFarlane] also looks at natural art. "Sculptures like the Moeraki boulders, the Cathedral Cliffs at Gore Bay, the Oamaru stone quarry.

The Moeraki boulders are impressive, the largest two metres in diameter and weighing several tonnes. An unexplained phenomon, the boulders are believed to be 60 millions years old and lie scattered on Moeraki Beach like great soccer balls.
The Ngai Tahu Trust Board has completed the purchase of the Moeraki Boulder Park complex near Oamaru.
The irregularity in composition of the Moeraki boulders is so great that it would be practically impossible to manufacture cement from them of a uniform quality.

Mohua were once the most common native birds in [sic] South Island; today, this valley is the only place they are found on the mainland.. The mohua's new home is a beautiful place.

New Zealand's native forests are being over-run by pests - possums, deer, rats and stoats. In the last 12 months, mohua/yellowhead populations were wiped out in the Eglinton Valley of Fiordland and on Mt Stokes in the Marlborough Sounds.

Since the rediscovery of mohua on the mountain in 1985, their numbers had painstakingly been built up from six to 90. But because ship-rat numbers built up over winter and rats moved for the first time into the mohua breeding zone, the result was a crash of the fragile population back to a critical level.

(false). The circumstances naturally caused much merriment among my audience, and quite upset the gravity of the venerable old chief Nepia Taratoa. `Friend,' said he, laughing, `your arguments are very good; but my mokai is a very wise bird, and he is not yet convinced.'

Climbing ferns are much less dominant in New Zealand bush than in tropical rainforest, but mokimoki (Microsorum scandens), Rumohra adiantiformis and thread fern (Blechnum filiforme) are common throughout, while jointed fern (Arthropteris tenella) and mangemange (Lygopodium articulatum) are characteristic of the warmer northern forest.

Author: THOMSON
Quote: First among the New Zealand list of disfigurations is tattooing, a Polynesian word signifying a repetition of taps, but which term is unknown in the language of the New Zealanders; moko being the general term for the tattooing on the face, and whakairo for that on the body.
It only so far denotes rank as showing that the possessor of a handsome moko must have had the wherewithal to well remunerate the artist.

Author: MORRIS
Quote: Moko, n. the system of tattooing practised by the Maoris. See Tattoo. It is not a fact - as popularly supposed - that the `moko' was distinctive in different families; serving, as is sometimes said, the purpose of a coat-of-arms. The `moko' was in fact all made on the same pattern - that of all Maori carvings. Some were more elaborate than others. The sole difference was that some were in outline only, some were half filled in, and others were finished in elaborate detail.
Mó.kó., (m&omacr.́.ko.́.), n. [Maori.] The kind of tattooing practiced among the higher ranks of the Maoris. ... Mó.ko, v. t. To tattoo in the Maori manner.

moko, tattooing on the face or body: - `their bodies and faces were more marked with the black stains which they call Amoco; they had a broad spiral on each buttock,' Cook, Voyages, 26 Nov., 1769 (Ed. 3, 1785), vol. 3, p. 253. "but the grand ornament of all was the moko, or tattoo; this was in general use, all ranks adopted it; a papatea, or plain face, was a term of reproach." Taylor, Ika, Ed. 2 (1870) 319. `The term tattoo is not known in New Zealand; and the name given to the decorative marks in question ... in in New Zealand moko.' Robley, Moko (1896), 3. `The native name for tattooing ... is moko, the verb being ta, or ta moko, as it is usually employed.' Best, The Maori (1924), vol. 2, 546; (ta, a prefix having apparently a causative force similar to that of whaka.)

Author: R. GILBERD
Quote: `We might objectively and scientifically describe him, if he were ours, as a dog of mixed breeds - ... we would not be pleased if an acquaintance calls that dog a mongrel.' In town where dogs are kept largely for appearance and display `mongrel' I think has only one meaning - that a dog is of mixed breeding (with a note of disapproval or contempt). In the country mongrel has two independent meanings. (i) A dog of mixed blood. Objective - no emotional content. Indeed `pedigreed' is acquiring something of the mongrel taint, in that if a good dog has a pedigree it is mentioned with a faint note of surprise. (ii) A `no-good' whether man or animal. `He turned out mongrel' (Rod Macaulay speaking of a pedigreed mastiff that took to sheep worrying.) `When Bill brought him home I knew he'd turn out a mongrel. Sort of a cow-y look about his head.' (Walter Hull discussing a pedigreed `Totara Park' Friesian bull which proved sterile.)

Author: McARA
Quote: Moore filters: Large `baskets' of canvas-covered filter-frames weighing about 16 tons and connected to a vacuum Source. First the basket was lowered by an overhead electric-crane into a tank of thickened pulp, previously treated with cyanide solution for several days. The vacuum caused a layer or cake of slime one or two inches thick to build up on the frames, while the clean solution, now laden with gold and silver, was pumped to the precipitators. When the cake reached the required thickness the basket was lifted and placed in a tank of barren cyanide solution, which was sucked through the cake removing the residual gold-bearing solution. After this the basket was placed in a `wash water' tank to remove all the solution, and then it was lifted and placed over the discharge bay; the vacuum was then released, allowing the cake to fall off (with some encouragement from a wooden scraper) into a waste sluice. [328] This process was repeated at about two-hourly intervals, with several bays working at the same time.

A black-skinned, curly-headed people with timid dispositions, presumably negroid or Melanesian, were supposed to have been found in possession of New Zealand by the first Polynesian settlers and exterminated by them except for a few with whom they intermarried, so that their racial traits appeared from time to time among the Maoris.

Author: MANING

Pakehas who knew no better called the muru simply `robbery', because the word Muru, in its common signification, means to plunder. But I speak of the regular legalized and established system of plundering as penalty for offences, which in a rough way resembled our law by which a man is obliged to pay `damages'.

Author: TREGEAR

Muster.-A city correspondent asks for the names of the various musters on high country stations. So far as I know the usual ones are (beginning in spring): the cutting and tailing m.; shearing m.; straggle m.(in old days the shorn sheep were always turned out before the country was straggled, so that they would lead the woolies in); dipping or weaning m. (to wean the lambs and dip the ewes); fall (or autumn) m.; straggle again; then scratch m. or `look over' to get the last of the sheep off the summer country before winter. This last is an undress sort of m., the men catching what stragglers they can in the basins. There are always other partial ms. of the flock; e.g., ewes to ram or eye clipping of hoggets.

Sheep dog.- Dog to work sheep; collie (q.v.). S.ds. run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that bring sheep are called heading ds. (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to lead (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to huntaway and are called htwys (q.v.). Some dogs will both hd. and htwy and are called handy ds. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special slewing d., but a well-trained, hdg. dog or htwy. will usually slew (q.v.). (C.)
Sheep dogs are of three distinct classes - the show dog, or fancy-worker, the mustering or paddock dog, and the yard or forcing dog.
The utility dog is a different class of animal. He is of two kinds - the mustering dog and the yard dog.
This great strain is known for noise, their terrific stamina and strong running qualities as mustering dogs.

Author: McLINTOCK
Quote: MUTTONBIRD. Also known as the sooty shearwater or titi, the New Zealand muttonbird is Puffinus griseus and belongs to the order of sea birds known as petrels. As a name, `muttonbird' appears to have originated among early European settlers in Australasia and is said to refer to the taste of the flesh. At least as probable is the theory that the name refers to the rather woolly appearance of the downy young. In New Zealand other petrels are also given the name `muttonbird'. In fact, the sooty shearwater, which is most abundant on the islands about Foveaux Strait, might well be called the southern muttonbird, and the grey-faced petrel, predominant on the islands off the coast of Auckland Province,the northern muttonbird. In Victoria, Tasmania, Bass Strait, and South Australia, the species is the short-tailed shearwater - an occasional visitor to New Zealand seas.

Author: HEAPHY
Quote: The native method of catching this [kahawai] is singular, and worthy of notice. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. In the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga).
